C3mT4aYl.title: Preparation and properties of chitosan nanocomposites with nanofillers of different dimensions
C3mT4aYl.abstract: In this work, the chitosan ternary nanocomposites with two-dimensional (2D) clay platelets and one-dimensional (1D) CNTs have been successfully prepared by a simple solution-intercalation/mixing method in acid media. It was found that the thermal degradation temperature of chitosan (at 50% weight loss) could be only improved in about 20–30 °C by adding 3 wt% either clay or CNTs, however, almost 80 °C increase of degradation temperature could be achieved by adding 2 wt% clay and 1 wt% CNTs together. Dynamic mechanical measurement demonstrated an obviously improved storage modulus for chitosan/clay–CNTs than that for the corresponding binary chitosan/clay or chitosan/CNT nanocomposites with the same total filler content (3 wt%). For the solvent vapor permeation properties, a largely improved benzene vapor barrier property was observed only in chitosan/clay–CNT ternary nanocomposites and depended on the ratio of clay to CNTs. XRD, SEM and TEM results showed that both clay and CNTs could be well dispersed in the ternary nanocomposites with the nanotubes located around the clay platelets. FTIR showed an improved interaction between the fillers and chitosan by using both clay and CNTs. A much enhanced solid-like behavior was observed in the ternary nanocomposites, compared with the corresponding binary nanocomposites with the same total filler content, as indicated by rheological measurement. The unique synergistic effect of two-dimensional (2D) clay platelets and one-dimensional (1D) CNTs on the property enhancement could be tentatively understood as due to a formation of much jammed filler network with 1D CNTs and 2D clay platelets combined together. Our work demonstrates a good example for the preparation of high performance polymer nanocomposites by using nanofillers with different dimensions together. Keywords Chitosan Clay Carbon nanotube Nanocomposite 1 Introduction In recent years, much attention has been paid to natural polymers due to the energy crisis and environmental problem [1–3] . Chitosan, poly-β(1,4)-2-amino-2-deoxy- d -glucose, is the deacetylated products of chitin, the second abundant natural polymer on earth [4] . Chitosan has been widely studied for biosensors, tissue engineering, separation membrane, and water treatment and so on, because of its good biocompatibility, biodegradability, and multiple functional groups [5] . However, low mechanical properties, thermal stability, and barrier of chitosan restrict its use in a wide-range application. Nanocomposite technology using nanofillers such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs), clay, and silica has already proved to be an effective way to improve the mechanical, electrical, and thermal properties of polymers [6–9] . Carbon nanotubes as one-dimensional (1D) nanomaterials are used for a variety of applications, because of their unique mechanical, electrical, thermal properties as well as large aspect ratio [10–14] . For example, with incorporation of only 0.8% CNTs into chitosan, the mechanical properties were greatly improved [15] . On the other hand, nanoclay as a two-dimensional (2D) material is also widely used in the preparation of polymer nanocomposites. Chitosan/clay composites were described in some literatures [16–19] . Because of the polycationic nature of the chitosan in acid media, this biopolymer can intercalate into the pristine clay by means of cationic exchange process in the absence of other organic modifiers. Intercalated and exfoliated nanostructures are formed in this system, which can provide strong interactions between the clay and chitosan. The enhanced thermal stability properties of chitosan were reported [18] , however, the extent of enhancement was not ideal, especially in the range of 200–400 °C. The study on filler network with different dimensions of nanofillers together in polymer is rarely reported. In recent years, an improved flame retardation of polymer was reported by adding carbon nanotube and clay simultaneously [20–23] . The thermal and flame retardant properties of the related ethylene–vinyl acetate (EVA) matrices were significantly enhanced when organo-modified clays and carbon nanotubes were added simultaneously [23] . Zhang et al. have successfully grown carbon nanotubes on clay platelet to form 3D nanostructure filler [24] . The tensile modulus and the tensile strength of the nylon-6 composite were greatly improved, by about 290% and 150%, respectively, by the incorporation of only 1 wt% CNT–clay hybrid filler due to the synergistic effect of CNTs and clay platelets for their homogeneous dispersion and strong interaction with the polymer matrix. However, fabrication of clay–CNT hybrid filler needs special conditions and high cost, and some new methods need to be explored. In this work, in order to investigate the synergistic effect of combination of 2D clay platelets and 1D CNTs on the properties of chitosan, the chitosan/clay–CNT ternary nanocomposites with fixed total filler content but changed ratio of clay to CNTs have been successfully prepared by a simple solution-intercalation/mixing method in acid media. It is crucial to have uniform filler dispersion within the polymer matrix and good interfacial adhesion between nanofillers and polymer matrix for making high performance nanocomposite. In one hand, the acidified CNTs attached to hydrophilic groups such as –COOH and –OH can be well dispersed in chitosan solution due to the hydrogen bond between chitosan and CNTs [15] . On the other hand, chitosan, a hydrophilic biopolymer, has –NH 2 and –OH in each unit. The amino group in chitosan can be protonated to NH 3 + in acid media, which is in favor of the intercalation of polymer chain into clay by means of a cationic exchange process [19] . Thus, a good dispersion of both clay and CNTs in chitosan solution is expected. The thermal stability, dynamic mechanical and solvent vapor transport properties of chitosan/CNT–clay nanocomposites were investigated, and a significant synergistic effect has been observed. The synergistic effect of 2D clay platelets and 1D CNTs was ascribed to (1) good dispersion of both clay and CNTs in chitosan matrix, as indicated by TEM, SEM and WAXD; (2) enhanced interaction between fillers and chitosan, as indicated by FTIR; and (3) enhanced fillers network by addition of both clay and CNTs, as indicated by rheological measurement. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Chitosan powder, with a deacetylation degree of 86% and a viscosity–average molecular weight of 345 000 g/mol, was bought from Zhejiang Golden-Shell Biochemical Co. Ltd. (Yuhuan, China). The unmodified pristine clay (Na + –montmorillonite), with a cationic exchange capacity (CEC) of 96 mequiv/100 g, was purchased from Southern Clay Products, Inc., TX. Multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWNTs, purity > 95%, diameter 10–30 nm, length 5–15 μm), manufactured by CVD, were purchased from Shenzhen Nanotech Port Co. (China). Benzene, glacial acetic acid, sulfuric acid (98%), and nitric acid (65%) were purchased from Kelong Chemical Reagent Plant (Chengdu, China). The raw MWNTs were treated in a mixture of concentrated sulfuric acid (98%)/nitric acid (3:1) at 30 °C for 24 h to increase the amounts of carboxylic and hydroxyl groups [25] . All reagents were of analytical grade. Distilled water was used throughout. 2.2 Preparation of the nanocomposite membranes A chitosan solution of 2% (w/v) was prepared by dissolving chitosan (CS) in a 2% (v/v) aqueous acetic acid solution followed by filtration to remove the impurity. The clay was first swelled in 40 mL of distilled water and ultrasonicated for 15 min by using ultrasonication tip (CF-300, 29 kHz, 150 W, Southwest Applied Acoustics Institute, Sichuan, China). Then, the clay suspension was added into the chitosan solution with clay content ranging from 1 to 3 wt% (with respect to chitosan), followed by stirring at 60 °C for 5 h. Subsequently, desired amount of CNT suspension was added into the mixture solution in various contents (1, 2 and 3 wt%). The stirring rate was kept at a speed of 400 rpm for 1 h. The resulting chitosan concentration in mixture solution was controlled to 2% (w/v) by evaporating water. The solutions were degassed for overnight under vacuum. After that, chitosan/clay/CNT solutions were poured into a glass plate and dried at 50 °C for 12 h to remove the solvents. The dried membranes were soaked in 2 wt% aqueous NaOH for 1 h to remove the acid and washed with water to neutrality and then dried at 50 °C for 5 h. The obtained membranes were peeled from the glass plate and stored at room temperature in a desiccator (RH = 50%). Mean thickness of the membranes was 50 μm. The samples were termed as chitosan/ x clay/ y CNTs (where x and y represent the weight contents of clay and CNTs, respectively). 2.3 Measurements and characterizations 2.3.1 Fourier transform infrared spectra Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were measured on a Nicolet560 spectrophotometer to investigate the interaction between chitosan and nanofillers in the range of 4000–400 cm −1 under a transmittance mode. The membrane samples were cut into some fragments, and these fragments were ground into powder. Then, the powder sample was mixed with KBr, and the resulting mixture was pressed into disks (about 0.3 mm in thickness) for FTIR test. 2.3.2 Wide-angle X-ray diffraction The structure of nanocomposites, especially, the state of intercalation of the clay was characterized by wide-angle X-ray diffraction (WAXD). X-ray experiment was performed using X' Pert Pro X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation ( λ = 0.15418 nm) under a voltage of 40 kV and a current of 40 mA. Samples were scanned over the range of diffraction angle 2 θ = 1–30° with a scan speed of 3°/min at room temperature. To measure the relative crystallinity ( X c ) of membrane, the amorphous areas and crystalline peak areas were measured, and X c was calculated from diffracted intensity data (2 θ = 6–30°) with the following relationship [21] : X c = [ A c / ( A c + A a ) ] × 100 % where A c and A a represent the areas of the crystalline and amorphous regions, respectively. 2.3.3 Thermogravimetric analysis The thermal stability of membranes was measured by the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, WRT-2P Shanghai Scale Factory). TGA was performed under nitrogen flows from 50 to 800 °C at a heating rate of 20 °C/min. The weights of the samples varied from 5 to 8 mg. To study the effect of nanofiller on formation of carbonaceous layer during heating, the char residues at 600 °C under nitrogen flows (after TGA test) were collected for scanning electron microscope (SEM) observation. 2.3.4 Electron microscopic observations The dispersion of nanofillers in matrix was observed via scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The fractured surface and char residues of the chitosan/clay/CNTs nanocomposites were observed by via SEM (JSM-5900LV) under an acceleration voltage of 20 kV. Before being examined, the membrane samples were cryogenically fractured in liquid nitrogen and coated with gold. Ultrathin sections with thicknesses of 50–70 nm for TEM observation were prepared via cutting from the epoxy block with embedded nanocomposite membranes at room temperature using a diamond knife. The TEM images were taken with transmission electron microscopy (JEM-2010) under an accelerated voltage of 200 kV. 2.3.5 Rheological measurements Oscillatory shear measurements were performed on a controlled stress RH7D rheometer (Bohlin Instruments Ltd) using 40-mm diameter cone and plate with a cone angle of 4°. Frequency sweep with an angular velocity between 0.01 and 100 rad/s was performed in the linear viscoelastic regime at a low stress of 3. The gap between the cone and the plate is 0.15 mm during measurement. The sample was allowed to equilibrate for at least 5 min at 25 °C before oscillatory shear measurements. 2.3.6 Water vapor permeability Water vapor permeability (WVP) of membranes was evaluated by a gravimetric test according to ATSM E96 and was performed at 30 °C. The detailed WVP measurement method can be found elsewhere [26] . Fifteen millilitres of water was introduced in each cup. The membranes were fixed on top of the cup and effective contact area was 2.53 cm 2 . The cups containing water were weighted, and then were place in an oven (RH = 30%, T = 30 °C). The weight of the cups was recorded every 2 h for a total of 24 h. Linear regression was used to calculate the slope of this line ( r 2 ≥ 0.996). Benzene vapor permeability of membranes was also determined by the method above. Three parallel measurements were carried out for each sample to obtain mean value. 2.3.7 Dynamic mechanical analysis Dynamic mechanical properties of the prepared composites (storage modulus, loss modulus and tan δ ) were characterized using a dynamic mechanical analyzer (DMA, Q800, TA Company) using tension membrane clamps, from 40 to 240 °C at a frequency of 1 Hz and a heating rate of 3 °C/min. The membrane was cut into the strip of 30 × 5 mm for DMA test. 3 Results 3.1 XRD analysis and electron microscopic images Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of pure clay (sodium montmorillonite), neat chitosan, chitosan/clay, chitosan/CNTs, and chitosan/CNT–clay composites with total filler content of 3 wt%. The basal spacing ( d 001 ) of pure clay has been calculated to be 1.2 nm from a diffraction peak at 2 θ = 7.2° using Bragg function. The characteristic peak of the clay disappears in the XRD spectrum for chitosan/CNT–clay composite when the clay content is less than 3 wt%, which means the formation of exfoliated structure of clay. The diffraction peak of chitosan/clay (3 wt%) is shifted to a lower angle (2 θ = 2.5°), showing an intercalated structure with the d -spacing of about 3.5 nm. This indicates that the layered clay is delaminated in the chitosan solution as the clay content is relatively low, whereas the intercalated structure is dominant when clay content becomes higher. It is noted that the diffraction peak in chitosan/clay composite is markedly sharpened compared to that in pure clay, indicating the enhanced ordered structure of clay in composite. Similar results were reported in other polymer/clay composites [40,41] . It could be explained as following reasons: (1) the distribution of interlayer spacing of clay become narrow after intercalation; (2) clay platelets can regularly arrange along a certain direction in chitosan membrane, compared to clay powder. Some researches also demonstrated that clay could easily orient parallel to the surface of solution-casting film [42,43] . The neat chitosan shows weak crystalline peaks around 2 θ = 11.3°, 18.2°, 23° in the XRD spectrum. The broadened peak around 2 θ = 23° indicates the existence of an amorphous structure. The crystalline peaks around 2 θ = 11.3°, 18.2°, 23° become somewhat stronger and sharper, accompanying a new peak at about 8.5°, after incorporating CNTs or clay into chitosan. The result suggests a higher crystallinity or denser packing in the main chain in comparison with the neat chitosan. This result is consistent with other reports in the literatures [15,18] . To see directly the dispersion of clay and CNTs in chitosan matrix, the TEM image of chitosan nanocomposite with 2 wt% clay and 1 wt% CNTs is shown in Fig. 2 . Fig. 2 a shows an exfoliated structure of clay platelets, which are randomly distributed in chitosan matrix, and meanwhile carbon nanotubes are observed to be well dispersed in chitosan. On the basis of the XRD results and TEM image, it can be concluded that the chitosan/CNT–clay nanocomposites with an exfoliated or intercalated structure of clay and well-dispersed CNTs have been successfully prepared through the simple solution-intercalation/mixing method. In Fig. 2 b (high magnification TEM image of Fig. 2 a), a part of CNTs indicated by white arrows is seen to be located around the clay platelets and form a kind of clay–CNT network, which could result in strong interaction between chitosan chains and the fillers. This result will be discussed in FTIR spectrum. Fig. 3 shows typical scanning electron microscope (SEM) images of fracture surface for (a) chitosan/2% clay/1% CNTs and (b) chitosan/1% clay/2% CNTs after brittle fracture in liquid nitrogen. The well-dispersed bright dots and lines are the end of CNTs and clay platelets. Fig. 3 a shows once again that CNTs and clay platelets can be well dispersed in chitosan matrix for chitosan/2% clay/1% CNTs composite, while some aggregates (remarked by black circle) are observed for chitosan/1% clay/2% CNT composite, as shown in Fig. 3 b. It is interesting to see here that the ratio of clay to CNTs also plays a role to determine the dispersion of fillers in the matrix. 3.2 Thermal stability The TGA curves of chitosan and its nanocomposite with various components under nitrogen flows are shown in Fig. 4 . In TGA, three parameters were measured: the temperature of thermal degradation at 20% weight loss, the temperature at 50% weight loss, and the yield of charred residue under nitrogen flow. One observes two steps of non-oxidative degradation. Firstly, the weight loss between 50 and 200 °C is attributed to the water absorbed in chitosan. Secondly, the weight loss in the temperature range of 200–400 °C corresponds to the degradation and deacetylation of chitosan. This is accorded with some literatures [17,18] . The summary of TGA result is listed in Table 1 . As degradation temperature at 50% loss weight is concerned, the thermal degradation temperature of chitosan is improved by about 20–30 °C after adding 3 wt% either clay or CNTs, however, almost 80 °C increase of degradation temperature has been achieved by adding 2 wt% clay and 1 wt% CNTs together, resulting in an increase of degradation temperature from 365 °C for pure chitosan to 442 °C for chitosan/2% clay/1% CNTs composite. The highest char residues (40.2% at 750 °C) are observed for this ternary nanocomposite. These results indicate a significantly synergistic effect of combination of 2D clay platelets and 1D CNTs on the thermal properties of chitosan. The large improvement of thermal stability of chitosan may rise from three reasons: (1) good heat barrier properties of CNTs and clay for polymer matrix during formation of chars [18] ; (2) formation of carbonaceous layer on the polymer surface at lower temperature [22] , which could hinder the flux of degradation product and heat flowing into underlying materials; (3) much jammed and conjugated 3D clay–CNT network, or strong interaction between chitosan and nanofillers could also restrict the polymer motion during heating (see below the FTIR and rheology results). It is interesting to see that the ratio of clay to CNTs also plays a role to determine the thermal stability. Chitosan/2% clay/1% CNT composites have the best thermal stability, and only mild increase of degradation temperature is seen for chitosan/1% clay/2% CNTs. 3.3 Dynamic mechanical properties The synergistic effect of combination of 2D clay platelets and 1D CNTs on the properties of chitosan can be further demonstrated by the measurement of dynamic mechanical properties. The storage modulus and tan δ of the chitosan and its composites with total filler content (3 wt%) but changed ratio of clay to CNTs, as a function of temperature, are shown in Fig. 5 . One observes an increase of storage modulus of chitosan by adding either 3 wt% clay or 3 wt% CNTs, as expected. However, the obvious increase of storage modulus is seen only for the ternary composites containing both clay and CNTs, in all the temperature range investigated. The storage modulus at 40 °C was improved by 56% from 3771 MPa for neat chitosan to 5899 MPa for chitosan/2% clay/1% CNT composites. The increase in storage modulus suggests that the interactions between chitosan matrix and CNTs or clay are strong enough to allow a very efficient load transfer to fillers, providing high mechanical strengths. Again the highest storage modulus is observed for chitosan/2% clay/1% CNT composites. On the other hand, one observes two peaks for all the samples. The one is located at around 90–100 °C, which is due to the evaporation of water absorbed. Some studies showed that the glass transition of chitosan was higher than 170 °C [27–29] ; hence, the peak located at around 180 °C could be considered as the glass transition temperature of chitosan. Although greatly increased storage modulus of chitosan is observed by adding clay or CNTs, the presence of CNTs, or clay, even both of them, does not significantly affect the peak position. Similar effects have been reported in other polymer systems filled with finely divided materials [6,30,31] . 3.4 The solvent vapor permeation properties The solvent vapor permeation properties were investigated in the work to show more evidences of synergistic effect of combination of 2D clay platelets and 1D CNTs on the properties of chitosan, the results are listed in Table 2 . Clays are considered as a good candidate for improving the barrier properties by creating a tortuous path for the molecule diffusion [32,33] , however, in the case of chitosan binary or ternary nanocomposites, the extent of barrier improvement for water vapor is not as obvious as expected by adding clay into chitosan matrix as it occurs in other polymers [34] . This result could be directly associated with the increased hydrophilic nature of chitosan due to the introduction of polar group from clay or acidified CNTs. The absorbed water molecules weaken the inter-molecular interactions of chitosan driving to dissolve more water and increasing the water diffusion rate, which lead to largely losing the barrier ability of clay in polymer [34] . In contrast to water vapor permeability, chitosan and its nanocomposites have a good barrier property for benzene vapor, as shown in Table 2 . With increasing of clay content in chitosan, benzene vapor permeation rate is obviously decreased from 18.8 g/m 2 d for neat chitosan to 7.45 g/m 2 d for chitosan/3% clay composite. It maybe attributed to an effect obstacle for benzene vapor diffusion due to the formation of clay network in chitosan and the enhanced crystallinity of polymer. Some literatures have reported that open-ended carbon nanotube could be used to increase the gas permeability in polymer by unique gas transport in nanochannel of carbon nanotube [35,36] , but not much change of permeability in chitosan/CNT composites is observed in our work, probably due to the increased crystallinity of chitosan by adding CNTs. Compared with neat chitosan and the binary composites, the largest improvement of barrier property of benzene vapor is observed in chitosan/2% clay/1% CNT composite, the benzene vapor permeation is further decreased to 4.2 g/m 2 d (see Table 2 ). Again the ratio of clay to CNTs also plays a role to determine the barrier property, for chitosan/1% clay/2% CNT composite, the benzene vapor permeation of 7.84 g/m 2 d is observed. It should be noted that the ratio of the water vapor permeation to benzene vapor permeation for the neat chitosan is changed from 81.7 to 330.7 for chitosan/2% clay/1% CNT composite. This much increased difference of membrane permeability between water vapor and benzene vapor could be well applied in pervaporation dehydration of benzene/water mixture. 3.5 FTIR analysis To understand the origin of the observed synergistic effect on the properties of chitosan by adding both 2D clay platelets and 1D CNTs, FTIR experiment was carried out and the result is shown in Fig. 6 . The FTIR spectrum of acidified CNTs shows two peaks at 3448 cm −1 , 1723 cm −1 , corresponding to OH and C O stretching, respectively. Clay platelets show –OH ( ν –OH ∼ 3632, 3447 cm −1 ) and Si–O–Si groups ( ν Si–O–Si ∼ 1050 cm −1 ), which could act as hydrogen-bonding sites for functional groups of chitosan. The strong bands at 1656 and 1599 cm −1 are ascribed to the amide I (C O stretching) and amide II (N–H blending modes) absorbance, respectively [18] . The effects of hydrogen bonding were taken into account for the intercalation of chitosan chain into negatively charged clay [37] . The amide band for chitosan with 3 wt% clay is shifted toward low frequency values as shown in Fig. 6 d, indicating a possible formation of hydrogen bonding between clay and chitosan. Fig. 6 e shows that the amide I ( ν C O ∼ 1656 cm −1 ) and amide II ( δ –NH2 ∼ 1599 cm −1 ) for chitosan/2% clay/1% CNTs are further shifted to lower frequency ( ν C O ∼ 1633 cm −1 and δ –NH2 ∼ 1599 cm −1 ). Meanwhile, –OH group band at 3455 cm −1 in chitosan is also shifted toward low frequency. This result indicates an enhanced hydrogen-bonding interaction between chitosan and the fillers by using both clay and CNTs. In some reports [37,38] , the intensity and location of Si–O–Si absorbance band are used to discuss the structure and morphology of clay in polymer matrix. Unfortunately, the change of Si–O–Si absorbance band is not observed in our case, due to the overlap of Si–O–Si absorbance band with C–O–C band of chitosan. 3.6 Rheological measurement Rheological measurement is a powerful tool for the investigating of interaction in a filled composite. The storage modulus G ′ under small-amplitude oscillatory shear in solution with 5% of chitosan or its composites is shown in Fig. 7 (we failed to carry out the rheological measurement on chitosan melt due to its easy degradation). In the high ω regime corresponding to the chain motion within small timescale, not much difference of the G ′ is seen for chitosan/clay, chitosan/CNT and chitosan/clay–CNT nanocomposites, which suggest that the movement of partial polymer chains, such as segment and amino group attached to the backbone, is not greatly influenced by nanofillers. However, the G ′ in the low ω regime is significantly different among the composites. The G ′ of chitosan/CNTs or chitosan/clay nanocomposite (the content of CNTs is 3 wt%) is slightly higher than that of basal polymer. One observes a very narrow plateau at low frequency regime for chitosan/clay composites. The frequency independence of G ′ at low frequency regime is regarded as a pseudo-solid-like behavior, and indicating a formation of percolating filler network. Within such locally correlated filler network, the relaxation of the chains upon the applied low-amplitude strain is incomplete at long time range, suggesting that the free movement of chains is restricted by the spatially confined geometry constituted by the anisotropic clay tactoids and nanoplatelets [39] . It is interesting to note a much enhanced G ′ and even broader plateau for chitosan/clay–CNT nanocomposites (with 2 wt% of clay and 1 wt% of CNTs), with respect to the chitosan nanocomposite with 3 wt% clay or CNTs. This very strong pseudo-solid-like behavior suggests a much higher degree of restricted relaxation behavior. 4 Discussion Combined with the FTIR and rheological measurement results, the unique synergistic effect of two-dimensional (2D) clay platelets and one-dimensional (1D) CNTs on the property enhancement could be tentatively understood as due to a formation of much jammed filler network by adding both 1D CNTs and 2D clay platelets. The possible mechanism of the 2D clay platelet network enhanced by adding 1D CNTs is schematically shown in Fig. 8 . In the chitosan with 3 wt% of clay, it is possible to form 2D clay platelet network, as indicated by rheological measurement ( Fig. 8 a). In chitosan/clay–CNT ternary nanocomposites, the 1D CNTs are located around 2D clay platelet network, or the 1D CNTs are confined in the 2D clay platelet network, resulting in a much jammed and conjugated 3D clay–CNT network ( Fig. 8 b). This proposed jammed and conjugated 3D clay–CNT network could be well used to explain the observed synergistic effect, such as the enhanced thermal stability and barrier property of benzene vapor. The surface morphology of the char of chitosan nanocomposites is shown in Fig. 9 . For the chitosan/3% CNT composite, some microcrack and large holes are observed in the char layer, which indicates the high weight loss of degradation product. The degradation temperature of chitosan/clay is higher than that of chitosan/CNTs and the former corresponds to the relatively dense and small pore structure in char. When clay and CNTs are added together into chitosan, the char is denser and has fewer cracks, as shown in Fig. 9 c. These results further support the existence of much stronger interaction between chitosan and nanofillers in the chitosan/clay–CNT composite. This much jammed and conjugated 3D clay–CNT network assists in formation of more compact carbonaceous layer on the polymer surface at lower temperature [18] , which could hinder the flux of degradation product and heat flowing into underlying materials. But, only mild increase of degradation temperature is seen for chitosan/1% clay/2% CNTs, which is probably associated with the dispersion of CNTs and incomplete filler network (with respect to chitosan/2% clay/1% CNTs). As shown in Fig. 3 b, the dispersion of CNTs in chitosan/1% clay/2% CNTs is relatively poor, which is a disadvantage for CNTs to bridge with clay platelets and form homogeneous carbonaceous layer for protecting the polymer from thermal degradation during formation of chars. As the barrier property is concerned, chitosan/2% clay/1% CNT composite has almost the same crystallinity with that in chitosan/3% clay and chitosan/1% clay/2% CNTs, as shown in the XRD pattern and Table 2 . But its barrier property is much better than the latter two, indicating a larger tortuosity in chitosan/2% clay/1% CNTs. Additions of CNTs or clay improve greatly the crystallinity of chitosan, which is an important factor for enhancement of barrier property of chitosan. Obviously here the crystallinity plays less important role in the further increase of the barrier properties for chitosan/clay–CNT ternary nanocomposites compared to chitosan/clay nanocomposites. Again, the more jammed and intact filler network formed in chitosan/2% clay/1% CNT composite will create a more effective path with larger tortuosity for diffusion of benzene vapor. Thus 3D filler network combined with 2D clay and 1D CNTs could be the key factor for the enhancement of barrier properties in this situation. More work is needed to further prove that using nanofillers with different dimensions could result in a much jammed and intact filler network. 5 Conclusion In summary, the chitosan/clay–CNT ternary nanocomposites with good thermal stability, storage modulus and barrier properties of benzene vapor have been successfully prepared by a simple solution-intercalation/mixing method in acid media. A great synergistic effect of 2D clay platelets and 1D CNTs (chitosan/2% clay/1% CNTs) for improving thermal stability, dynamic mechanical and barrier properties of chitosan matrix has been observed. This could be understood as due to a formation of 3D conjugated filler network with 1D CNTs inserted in the 2D clay platelet network, of which unique nanostructure provides larger tortuosity and obstacle for the transport of heat and benzene vapor. In this work, only a part of CNTs located in clay platelets network is observed as shown in TEM images, but we believe that larger extent of 1D CNTs inserted in the 2D clay platelet network will result in a larger improvement of chitosan property. Our work demonstrates a good example for the preparation of high performance polymer nanocomposites by using nanofillers of different dimensions together. These properties improved for chitosan will enlarge its application field, such as medicine material, plastic substitutes and pervaporation dehydration. 1GLth8Pz.title: Effect of melt temperature on the phase morphology, thermal behavior and mechanical properties of injection-molded PP/LLDPE blends
1GLth8Pz.abstract:
The phase morphology and thermal behavior of various isotactic polypropylene (PP)/linear low density polyethylene (LLDPE)
 blends were investigated with aid of scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), respectively.
 The effect of barrel (melt) temperature on the morphology, thermal behavior and the resultant mechanical properties of the
 injection molded bars was the research focus, and the influence of LLDPE composition was also taken into account. It was found
 that the mechanical properties, especially the tensile ductility and the impact strength, were greatly affected by the processing
 temperature. The samples obtained at low temperatures had the highest elongation at break and impact strength, while those
 molded at high temperatures had the poorest toughness. Two reasons were responsible for that: first, the phase size in the
 samples increased with the processing temperature; second, possible orientation existed in the samples obtained at low processing
 temperatures.

HTNAnueO.title: Surface modification of carbon nanotube and its influence on the conductivity property of carbon nanotube/fluoro-elastomer composite
HTNAnueO.abstract: Multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) were modified by mixed acid and tetrafluoro carbon (CF4) plasma treatment. The surface morphology and structure of MWCNTs before and after treatment were obtained by using SEM and XPS, which revealed that MWCNTs can be grafted by polar groups after surface treatment. Furthermore, MWCNTs/fluoro-elastomer (FE) composite films were prepared by the method of solution casting using untreated MWCNTs (UCNTs), acid-modified MWCNTs (ACNTs) and CF4 plasma-modified MWCNTs (FCNTs). In each case, MWCNTs mass fractions were 0.1%, 0.5%, 1.0% and 2.0% with respect to the polymer. The conductivity of MWCNTs/FE was studied by comparing the modification effect on MWCNTs. The results show that the lowest percolation threshold in acid-modified MWCNTs/FE composites was about 0.5%.

pMRucqDj.title: Effect of surface "groove" structure of carbon nanotube bundles on the formation of nanohybrid shish kebab
pMRucqDj.abstract: Nanohybrid shish kebab (NHSK) structure, in which fibrous carbon nanotubes (CNTs) act as shish, while polymer lamellae as kebab, is of particular interest both scientifically and technologically. In this work, two types of CNTs with the same diameter range and different topography structure, namely multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWNTs) with a relatively smooth surface and double-walled carbon nanotubes (DWNTs) bundles with a groove structure, were used to induce polyethylene (PE) crystallization for the formation of NHSK. For PE/MWNTs system, NHSK was formed only at a relatively low crystallization temperature (T c), and PE lamellae are not completely perpendicular to the long axis of MWNTs. However, for PE/DWNTs bundles system, NHSK could be obtained even at a much higher T c, and almost all the PE lamellae are perpendicular to CNTs long axis, due to the unique "groove structure" formed by DWNTs bundles. The enhanced nucleation ability and the facilitated lamellae orientation by using DWNTs bundles are not only of great crystallography interest but also are very important for functional design in nanodevice applications. © Materials Research Society 2012.

6W9edaEf.title: Improving impact toughness of polylactide/poly(ether)urethane blends via designing the phase morphology assisted by hydrophilic silica nanoparticles
6W9edaEf.abstract: Obtaining network-like morphology (rubber particles are unevenly distributed in the matrix, forming a discontinuous rubber network structure) has been considered to be an effective strategy to optimize the toughness of rubber-toughened polymers. However, it is very difficult to achieve using conventional processing method. In this work, taking elastomer-toughened polylactide (PLA) as an example, we attempt to use hydrophilic silica (SiO 2) nanoparticles with self-networking capability to control the phase morphology and the mechanical properties of PLA/poly(ether)urethane (PU) (85/15) blend. It is interesting to find that the selective localization of SiO2 nanoparticles in the PU phase and at the phase interface induces the morphological change from a common sea-island structure to a unique network-like structure constructed by discrete PU particles with irregular shapes, thus giving rise to a remarkable improvement in the impact toughness of the blend with strength and modulus unaffected. The formation of the network-like structure is attributed to the synergistic effect between the self-networking of the interface-localized SiO2 and the enhanced elasticity of the SiO2-localized PU phase. This inspiring result proves the introduction of nanoparticles with self-networking capability into polymers blends to be a universal platform to design their performance via tuning the phase structure. ? 2014 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

SDh8caPj.title: A change of phase morphology in poly(p-phenylene sulfide)/polyamide 66 blends induced by adding multi-walled carbon nanotubes
SDh8caPj.abstract: By adding a small amount of acid treated multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) into poly( p -phenylene sulfide)/polyamide 66 (60/40 w/w) blends, the morphology was found to change from sea–island to co-continuous structure. As the MWCNT content was increased, the morphology came back to sea–island but with increased domain size. It was very interesting to note that the MWCNTs were found to be selectively located in the PA66 phase, and their assembling determines the final morphology of PPS/PA66 blends. A dendritic contacted MWCNTs network was formed at low load, which leads to the formation of a co-continuous structure, and isolated MWCNT aggregates were observed at high load, which leads to the formation of sea–island morphology. Since the properties of multiphase polymeric materials are not only determined by the properties of the component polymers, but also by the morphology formed, our work indicates that the behavior of phase-separating polymer blends containing MWCNTs can be exploited to create a rich diversity of new structures and useful nanocomposites.

ybM6f4gf.title: Confine Clay in an Alternating Multilayered Structure through Injection Molding: A Simple and Efficient Route to Improve Barrier Performance of Polymeric Materials.
ybM6f4gf.abstract: Various methods have been devoted to trigger the formation of multilayered structure for wide range of applications. These methods are often complicated with low production efficiency or require complex equipment. Herein, we demonstrate a simple and efficient method for the fabrication of polymeric sheets containing multilayered structure with enhanced barrier property through high speed thin-wall injection molding (HSIM). To achieve this, montmorillonite (MMT) is added into PE first, then blended with PP to fabricate PE-MMT/PP ternary composites. It is demonstrated that alternating multilayer structure could be obtained in the ternary composites because of low interfacial tension and good viscosity match between different polymer components. MMT is selectively dispersed in PE phase with partial exfoliated/partial intercalated microstructure. 2D-WAXD analysis indicates that the clay tactoids in PE-MMT/PP exhibits an uniplanar-axial orientation with their surface parallel to the molded part surface, while the tactoids in binary PE-MMT composites with the same overall MMT contents illustrate less orientation. The enhanced orientation of nanoclay in PE-MMT/PP could be attributed to the confinement of alternating multilayer structure, which prohibits the tumbling and rotation of nanoplatelets. Therefore, the oxygen barrier property of PE-MMT/PP is superior to that of PE-MMT because of increased gas permeation pathway. Comparing with the results obtained for PE based composites in literature, outstanding barrier property performance (45.7% and 58.2% improvement with 1.5 and 2.5 wt % MMT content, respectively) is achieved in current study. Two issues are considered responsible for such improvement: enhanced MMT orientation caused by the confinement in layered structure, and higher local density of MMT in layered structure induced denser assembly. Finally, enhancement in barrier property by confining impermeable filler into alternating multilayer structure through such simple and efficient method could provide a novel route toward high-performance packaging materials and other functional materials require layered structure.
keywords: high speed thin wall injection molding

XeNh1Vch.title: Largely Improved Stretch Ductility and <Emphasis Type="Italic">β</Emphasis>-Form Room-temperature Durability of Poly(vinylidene fluoride) by Incorporating Aliphatic Polyketone
XeNh1Vch.abstract: In this study, we attempt to prepare a new blending system of poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) and aliphatic polyketone (POK) by melt compounding. The latter is a promising engineering plastic with comprehensive mechanical performances. When POK acted as minor phase to homogeneously disperse in and intimately contact with PVDF matrix, the brittle tensile behavior of neat PVDF transferred into a remarkably flexible manner (the elongation at break increased for 20 times), and more interestingly, the room-temperature durability of β-form PVDF in the uniaxially drawn blend film was obviously better than that in the neat PVDF film. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy revealed that specific dipole interaction existed between CF2 group of PVDF and C=O group of POK. The intermolecular dipolar interaction induced good compatibility in the PVDF/POK blends, as evidently proved by fine two-phase morphology and decreased melting points of POK crystals. Therefore, the good compatibility and interfacial enhancement are responsible for the improvement of the stretch ductility and β-form room-temperature durability of the PVDF/POK blends.

eEZI1BbJ.title: Study on dispersion polymerization of styrene based on uniform design
eEZI1BbJ.abstract: In this paper,the uniform design methods were used to arrange four-factor and eight-level experiment of dispersion polymerization of styrene,including monomer concentration,initiator concentration,stabilizer concentration and ratio of alcohol and water.The stepwise regression technique was adopted to analyze the test results.The mathematical modes between molecular weight,size and size distribution of PS and four influencing factors were established,and their reliabilities were evaluated.Although the predicted values from regression equation were different from the observed values(relative divergences were less than 15%),the regression equation could use for design of polystyrene particles and mechanism research.All above researches could use for optimization of dispersion polymerization reaction conditions.

pjrzlEj9.title: Properties comparison of mullite and precipitated silica-filled styrene-butadiene rubber composites
pjrzlEj9.abstract: Mullite filled styrene-butadiene rubber(SBR) composites were prepared on a two-roll mill with untreated or treated mullite(by mass fraction of 3% A-189) as fillers.The effects of these fillers on properties of filled SBR at various loadings were investigated,and the comparison was conducted with those of SBR filled with precipitated silica.The results showed that mullite was a semi-reinforcing filler for SBR and the mullite filled SBR exhibited better overall cure properties,lower Mooney viscosity,lower permanent set,better resilience as compared to those of precipitated silica filled ones,while other properties were inferior to those of precipitated silica filled ones,especially with regard to tensile strength,tear strength and abrasion resistance.The presence of the silane coupling agent could enhance the mechanical properties of mullite filled SBR vulcanizates.

BvqqLXOK.title: The variable role of clay on the crystallization behavior of DMDBS-nucleated polypropylene
BvqqLXOK.abstract: The effect of clay on the nucleating behavior of 1,3:2,4-bis(3,4- dimethylbenzylidene) sorbitol (DMDBS) in cryatallization of isotactic polypropylene (iPP) was investigated by means of differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), dynamic rheology and polarized light microscopy (PLM). It is interesting to note that the incorporation of layered clay nanoparticles into DMDBS-nucleated iPP may induce a synergetic nucleation effect while the DMDBS content is below 0.1 wt%, otherwise it restricts the crystallization rate prominently as the DMDBS content increases up to 0.3 wt%, which has exceeded the content threshold to yield a nucleating agent (NA) network. As shown by dynamic rheological investigations, the clay nanoparticles demonstrate an obstructive effect of disturbing the consistency of DMDBS fibrils network. Moreover, to further demonstrate the importance of NA network formation in the crystallization of iPP, we used another NA named HPN-20e, which can not form network structure at all over the concentration studied, for comparison. In this case, the nucleated-crystallization rate is independent on the addition of clay nanoparticles, as the nucleating mechanism is an individual nuclei manner without NA network forming. © Chinese Chemical Society.

rEOJxhTT.title: Unexpected molecular weight dependence of shish-kebab structure in the oriented linear low density polyethylene/high density polyethylene blends.
rEOJxhTT.abstract: In this study, highly oriented shish-kebab structure was achieved via imposing oscillatory shear on the melts of linear low density polyethylene (LLDPE)/high density polyethylene (HDPE) blends during the packing stage of injection molding. To investigate the effect of molecular weight of HDPE on the formation of shish-kebab structure, two kinds HDPE with large melt flow index (low molecular weight) and small melt flow index (high molecular weight) were added into LLDPE matrix. The structural characteristics of LLDPE/HDPE blends were systematically elucidated through two-dimensional wide-angle x-ray scattering, scanning electron microscopy, and differential scanning calorimetry. Interestingly, an unexpected molecular weight dependence of shish-kebab structure of the prepared samples was found that the addition of HDPE with low molecular weight resulted in an higher degree of orientation, better regularity of lamellar arrangement, thicker lamellar size, and higher crystal melting temperature than that adding HDPE with high molecular weight. Correspondingly, the blend containing low molecular weight HDPE had better tensile strength. A possible mechanism was suggested to elucidate the role of HDPE molecular weight on the formation of shish-kebab structure in the oriented blends, considering the change of chain mobility and entanglement density with change of molecular weight.

zx9bwYbG.title: New insight on the annealing induced microstructural changes and their roles in the toughening of β-form polypropylene
zx9bwYbG.abstract: Large amount of work has been reported on the annealing of polypropylene (PP) and the related changes in mechanical properties. However, the structure-property correlations and the physical origin of annealing induced microstructural evolution are still not very clear. In this work, taking β-form PP (β-PP) as example, the microstructural changes induced by annealing were investigated from macromolecular to crystalline lamellae level with Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy, conventional differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), temperature-modulated DSC (TMDSC), wide-angle X-ray diffraction (WAXD), small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) and dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA). Besides mobile amorphous fraction (MAF), the role of rigid amorphous fraction (RAF) in toughening PP is particularly taken into consideration. It is shown that annealing increases the chain mobility in MAF and decreases it in RAF. Such an effect is believed to be mainly associated with the formation of looser MAF and more RAF by the microstructural re-arrangement involving conformational ordering of partial amorphous chain segments and a significant interlamellae thickening. A thorough analysis of structure-property relationship through observing plastic deformation behaviors by scanning electron microscope (SEM) and estimating stress transmission between crystalline and amorphous phases, suggests that both MAF and RAF play important role on toughening β-PP. They can promote the initiation of microvoids effectively upon deformation by reducing the stress transmission. As a result, large-scale plastic deformation is triggered. This work is important and provides a new insight into the mechanisms of microstructural evolution and subsequent improvement in impact toughness during annealing. © 2011 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

6yvMJ2TP.title: Toughening of poly(l-lactide) with poly(ε-caprolactone): Combined effects of matrix crystallization and impact modifier particle size
6yvMJ2TP.abstract: Enhancing matrix crystallization has been demonstrated to be an effective method to simultaneously improve the impact toughness and heat resistance of poly(l-lactide) (PLLA) modified with flexible polymers, such as poly(ε-caprolactone) (PCL). Unfortunately, increasing PLLA matrix crystallinity alone cannot guarantee the enhancement of impact toughness in most cases, so other structural parameters should be considered. In this work, taking PLLA/PCL (80/20) blend as an example, the combined roles of matrix crystallization and impact modifier particle size in the toughening have been investigated. PLLA matrix crystallinity was controlled by adding a highly effective nucleating agent and PCL particle size was tailored by varying processing conditions while maintaining constant interfacial adhesion. It is interesting to find that toughening is efficient only if matrix crystallinity and particle size are well matched. With the significant increase of matrix crystallinity, an evident decrease of optimum particle size for toughening PLLA has been identified for the first time. Therefore, suitable particle size is the precondition for highly crystalline matrix to work effectively in the toughening because only small particles (0.3-0.5 μm) are effective in trigger shear yielding mechanism of the matrix needed for good toughness, whereas relatively large particles (0.7-1.1 μm) are only capable of toughening amorphous matrix effectively by initiating multiple crazing of the matrix. Importantly, our findings can be used to well explain the reason for the different roles of matrix crystallization in the toughening of different PLLA blends reported in the literature. Furthermore, the heat resistance of the blend with a highly crystalline matrix is much better than that of the blend with an amorphous one as expected. This work could not only provide a new insight into the synergistic roles of matrix crystallization and modifier particle size in the toughening of PLLA but also set up a universal framework for designing high-performance PLLA products with both good impact toughness and high heat resistance. © 2013 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sVGxkAqn.title: Effects of clay on phase morphology and mechanical properties in polyamide 6/EPDM-g-MA/organoclay ternary nanocomposites
sVGxkAqn.abstract: In this study, both organoclay and EPDM- g -MA rubber were used to simultaneously improve the toughness and stiffness of polyamide 6 (PA6). We first prepared PA6/EPDM- g -MA/organoclay ternary nanocomposites using melt blending. Then the composites were subjected to traditional injection molding and so-called dynamic packing injection molding. The dispersion of clay, phase morphology, crystallinity and orientation of PA6 as well the mechanical properties were characterized by WAXD, SEM, DSC, 2D-WAXS and mechanical testing, respectively. The effects of clay on phase morphology and mechanical properties of PA6/EPDM- g -MA blends could be summarized as follows: (1) weakening interphase adhesion between PA6 and EPDM- g -MA rubber particles, resulted in increasing of rubber particle size, as the clay and rubber contents are low; (2) preventing coalescence of rubber domains, arisen in decreasing of rubber particle size, as the clay and rubber contents are high; (3) the blocking effect on the overlap of stress volume around rubber particles caused broadening of the brittle–ductile transition region and decrease of toughness, and (4) the effective stress transfer leading a better reinforcement when the interparticle distance is smaller than the critical value.

6SjlUs9w.title: A new technique for preparing polyethylene/polystyrene blends with gradient structure

tl8cNvKk.title: Origin of various lamellar orientations in high-density polyethylene/isotactic polypropylene blends achieved via dynamic packing injection molding: bulk crystallization vs. epitaxy
tl8cNvKk.abstract: Epitaxial growth of high-density polyethylene (HDPE) onto lamellae of isotactic polypropylene (iPP), with HDPE chains inclined about 50° to that of iPP, has been achieved for the first time in their blends via dynamic packing injection molding. Even more, the epitaxial growth was found to be dependent on composition of the blends. The sequence of crystallization is not the dominant factor, but the fact that iPP crystallizes before HDPE is prerequisite for epitaxial growth of PE. Various lamellar orientations with composition can be explained by the competition between bulk crystallization and epitaxy at interfaces (i.e. iPP lamellae). In 20PP (20 wt% iPP by weight in blends), HDPE can readily crystallize in the bulk as a result of shear, and no epitaxial growth of PE is observed. For 80PP, however, bulk crystallization of HDPE can be depressed due to lack of nuclei in its bulk, resulting from a much finer droplets dispersed in the iPP matrix, and then epitaxial growth prevails.

pHdYbbFc.title: Design,preparation and properties of biomedical phospholipid polyurethanes
pHdYbbFc.abstract: Polyurethanes(PUs) have been widely used in various biomedical devices due to their excellent physical properties and relatively good biocompatibility.However,many adverse biological reactions in vivo are triggered by the virgin surfaces of PUs,such as protein adsorption,blood coagulation,complement activation,and thrombogenicity,etc.,which have hindered their more widespread applications in medicine.The biomembrane-mimicking phospholipid polymers as surface modifiers to improve hemocompatibility of various biomaterials have attracted more attention because of their excellent biocompatibility with the human tissue.Thus,phospholipid PUs are believed as one of the most promising avenues to improve biocompatibility of PUs.This review focuses on the recent progress of phospholipid PUs studies on their structure design,preparation,and biocompatibility evaluation.In particularly,the applications of fluorinated phospholipid polyurethanes and biodegradable phospholipid polyurethanes for drug delivery are highlighted,which will open up a new era in the development of biomedical polyurethanes.

3ynwef6Y.title: A Robust, Mechanically and Electrically Self-Healing Hydrogel for Efficient Electromagnetic Interference Shielding.
3ynwef6Y.abstract: Autonomously self-healing hydrogels have received considerable attentions owe to their capacity for repairing themselves spontaneously after suffering damage, which can provide better stability and longer lifespan. In this work, a robust, mechanically and electrically self-healing hydrogel with efficient electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding performance was successfully fabricated via the incorporation of multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) into the hydrophobically associated polyacrylamide (PAM) hydrogels by using cellulose nanofiber (CNF) as dispersant. It has been found that CNF could not only assist the homogeneous dispersion of MWCNTs, but also effectively enhance the mechanical property of the resultant hydrogels. As a result, the optimal tensile strength (≈ 0.24 MPa), electrical conductivity (≈ 0.85 S m-1) and EMI shielding effectiveness (≈ 28.5 dB) were achieved for the PAM/CNF/MWCNT composite hydrogels with 1 wt% MWCNTs and 0.3 wt% CNF, which showed 458%, 844% and 90% increase than those (≈ 0.043 MPa, ≈ 0.09 S m-1 and ≈15 dB, respectively) of PAM hydrogel. More encouragingly, these composite hydrogels could rapidly restore their electrical conductivity and EMI shielding effectiveness after mechanical damage at room temperature without any external stimulus. With outstanding mechanical and self-healing properties, the prepared composite hydrogels are similar to human skin, but beyond human skin owing to their additional satisfactory electrical and EMI shielding performances. They may offer promising and broad prospects in the field of simulate skin and protection of precision electronics.

LzHZzCfv.title: Dependence of mechanical properties on β-form content and crystalline morphology for β-nucleated isotactic polypropylene

foT9wwIp.title: Towards high-performance polypropylene and its random copolymer: Insight into toughening mechanism of supercritical carbon dioxide assisted annealing
foT9wwIp.abstract: A supercritical carbon dioxide (scCO2) assisted annealing technique is adopted to toughen polypropylene (PP) and its random copolymer with 3.8 wt% co-monomer content (PPR). By using this technique, PP with 4-time improvement in toughness or PPR with superior toughness are obtained. Meanwhile, the stiffness of the materials could be maintained. To understand the toughening mechanism, scanning electron microscope, wide angle X-ray diffraction, calorimetry, dynamic mechanical analysis and small angle X-ray scattering characterizations are carried out. It is demonstrated that the toughening mechanism is strongly related to the microstructure evolutions, including decreased chain density in the mobile amorphous phase, improved crystalline phase and improved rigid amorphous phase after annealing. These microstructure changes could result in higher cavitation ability and diminish inner stress in the amorphous phase, which consequently favors improvement in toughness. ? 2014 Elsevier B.V.
